title: Science Weekly: The Hidden Face of Research
author: Ilia Blinderman
header-title__top: Contents lists available at The Pudding
intro: Welcome to The Pudding’s Science Weekly. This is the first of 4 pieces devoted to exploring little-known scientific findings about science. Specifically, the unexpected or underappreciated aspects of how we do science, and its implications.

background.value: Science, so the popular belief goes, involves standing on the shoulders of giants: at its core, it entails conducting experiments, submitting the results to a group of expert peers, and publishing the summary in a journal for others to refer to in their own studies. As researchers, we tend to see these results as trustworthy, and base our careers — our research interests, grant applications, and years of graduate school — on the contents of these published results.

But what happens when trust in science erodes? Psychology, my field of study for nearly a decade, is facing just such a crisis. Power poses? Highly questionable. The popular conception of implicit bias? Thoroughly suspect. What to do?

First, in addition to supplying a methodology section to every experimental study, we can give researchers access to the relevant raw data to analyze for themselves. But things aren’t quite as simple. I’ll explain why.

part-1: In 2013, a group of researchers led by UBC’s Timothy Vine found that the availability of research data declines rapidly with article age*. Say you’re a researcher, and you want to conduct a replication of some analysis that people have been citing for years, because you’ve got a hunch that conclusions aren’t airtight; there’s a 90% likelihood that these data just aren’t around anymore. But what does that really mean, in concrete terms? How much of our work, as scientists, is the equivalent of an iceberg tip whose bottom melted away?
part-2: Here’s a portion of my Master’s thesis, submitted the same year as paper you just saw. The whole thesis relies on the literature review you see here, where I scoured the available evidence to set frame my hypothesis about the impact of our psyche on physiological symptoms. Were I to seek the original data used in these studies, let’s see how likely I’d be to obtain it according to the probabilities in the paper we first discussed.
part-3: I’ve color-coded each sentence that included a citation to past research. Dark passages are more likely to have data behind the studies; light ones are likely missing the raw data which led to the findings in the first place.
part-4: Here’s how much of the paper disappears if we remove the studies that almost certainly have no data behind them.

part-5.value: Let’s drop everything that’s 70% likely to have absent data. The amount of findings that I relied on in this literature review that’s available for others to reassess is drastically reduced here.

methods-and-caveats.value: *these findings pertain to biological data found in biology journals; the specific numbers may very well differ based on discipline.
